nodes.text: Physics-based models (Ising-type models and agent-based computational models) can better explain out-of-equilibrium phenomena of financial markets (excess volatility, fat tails, volatility clustering, bubbles and crashes) than standard representative-agent equilibrium models and provide useful predictive and diagnostic tools

Traditional financial economics relies on representative agents, rational expectations and equilibrium assumptions that fail to capture agent heterogeneity, interactions and out-of-equilibrium phenomena

The Ising model and its statistical physics analogs map to discrete choice with social interaction: random utility + Gumbel noise -> Logit probabilities analogous to Boltzmann factors, yielding Ising-like collective dynamics

Agent-based models (ABMs) provide a computational framework to simulate heterogeneous interacting agents, allow out-of-equilibrium dynamics, learning, adaptation and endogenous emergence of macro patterns
Generalized kinetic Ising models and ABMs reproduce many stylized facts of financial markets: fat-tailed return distributions, volatility clustering, multifractality, intermittent bubbles and crashes

Empirical evidence and testing: log-periodic power law (LPPL) precursors, diagnostics of bubble phases, and the Financial Crisis Observatory forecasts provide retrospective and some prospective support for endogenous bubble signatures

The excess volatility puzzle (prices more volatile than fundamentals) is explained by noise-induced volatility, herding and positive feedbacks in Ising-like/ABM frameworks rather than by flawed data under an efficient equilibrium interpretation

Quantum decision theory (QDT) formalizes composite prospects in a Hilbert-space framework: prospect probability = utility factor + attraction (interference) term, quantitatively accounting for decision anomalies and entanglement effects

Emerging Market Intelligence Hypothesis: the collective aggregation of many intelligent strategies produces market-level intelligence that renders most individual strategies effectively 'noise traders', explaining pervasive trading and apparent irrationality

Social bubble hypothesis: strong social interactions and positive feedbacks create collective over-enthusiasm that fuels bubbles; such bubbles can be necessary for large-risk innovation despite systemic instability

Calibration and validation of large ABMs remain an outstanding limitation: high dimensionality, nonlinear dynamics, ill-conditioned likelihoods and data constraints impede robust parameter estimation and wide adoption by policy makers
Conclusion: combining physics, computational agent-based methods and evolutionary/biological perspectives is required to advance realistic models of financial markets and systemic risk
